items.title: Lecornu bemoans lack of compromise across political spectrum as he resigns as French PM ‚Äì Europe live
items.content_html:
Departure after less than a month follows fierce criticism of Macron‚Äôs new cabinet

Just as most across France were starting their workday, news broke that the country‚Äôs prime minister, S√©bastien Lecornu, had resigned.

The swift, unexpected resignation came after allies and foes alike threatened to topple the new government, leaving Lecornu blaming the ‚Äúegos‚Äù of opposition politicians.

Lecornu was President Emmanuel Macron‚Äôs fifth prime minister in two years. He stayed in the job for only 27 days and his government lasted 14 hours.

The resignation deepens the political crisis that has gripped France for more than a year, after Macron called legislative elections in the summer of 2024 which ended in a hung parliament.

Macron‚Äôs opponents immediately seized on the moment. The far-right National Rally called on him to either call for new snap elections or resign while across the spectrum on the left, France Unbowed also called for Macron‚Äôs departure.

items.title: Term ‚Äòdisabled‚Äô being used too widely, shadow work and pensions secretary says ‚Äì UK politics live
items.content_html:
Helen Whateley says ‚Äòmillions are sitting on the sofa at home‚Äô

Mel Stride, the shadow chancellor, was doing an interview round for the Conservatives this morning, and Miatta Fahnbulleh, the faith and communities minister, was on the air on behalf of the government. They were both asked about the latest development in the flag phenomenon ‚Äì the former footballer turned property developer Gary Neville saying that he took down a union flag flying at one of his building sites because he felt it was being used in a ‚Äúnegative fashion‚Äù.

Asked if Neville (a Labour supporter) had a point, Fahnbulleh told ITV‚Äôs Good Morning Britain:

I think he‚Äôs really right, that there are people who are trying to divide us at the moment ‚Ä¶

I spent a lot of time going around our communities, talking to people. People are ground down. We‚Äôve had a decade-and-a-half in which living standards haven‚Äôt budged and people have seen their communities held down. And you will get people trying to stoke division, trying to blame others, trying to stoke tension.

I think people that put up flags, the vast majority of people that do, do so for perfectly reasonable patriotic reasons. And I think reclaiming our flag as a flag of unity and decency and tolerance, which is the way most people see our flag, is a very positive thing.

So I‚Äôm afraid I really cannot agree with the comments that he‚Äôs made.

items.content_html:
Janjaweed commander Ali Muhammad Ali Abd-al-Rahman, known as Ali Kushayb, found guilty over atrocities

The international criminal court has convicted a leader of the Janjaweed militia of playing a leading role in a campaign of atrocities committed in the Sudanese region of Darfur more than 20 years ago.

It was the first time the court had convicted a suspect of crimes in Darfur. The court ruled that the atrocities, including mass murders and rapes, were part of a government plan to snuff out a rebellion in the western region of Sudan.

items.title: Weather tracker: Typhoon Matmo batters southern China
items.content_html:
About 350,000 flee homes as heavy rain and winds sweep region, while Hurricane Priscilla forms near Mexico

Typhoon Matmo made landfall on the southern coast of China on Sunday afternoon, shortly after sweeping across the island province of Hainan. The powerful storm forced the evacuation of about 350,000 people, bringing torrential rain and damaging winds, especially between Wuchuan in Guangdong and Wenchang in Hainan. Ferry services were suspended and flights cancelled at Haikou Meilan airport.

Matmo, the 21st typhoon of the year, had sustained wind speeds of 94mph (151km/h) and dumped more than 50mm of rainfall in six hours in Chongzou and Qinzhou. The city of Nanning also had high rainfall totals.

items.content_html: The former mayor of Kherson, Volodymyr Mykolaienko, was held captive for three years before being released in a prisoner exchange. He spoke to DW about the occupation of his city, and surviving imprisonment in Russia.

items.title: Moldova: Ruling pro-EU party wins election
items.content_html: Moldovans voted in a high-stakes election to decide whether the country moves closer to the European Union or Russia. The defeated pro-Russian party has called for a protest against the results.

items.title: H3N2 influenza spreads rapidly in Delhi, northern India
items.content_html: An aggressive flu virus has gripped northern India. Two-thirds of families in the region are affected. Who's most at risk? And how can people protect themselves?

items.title: At least 40 dead and 124 injured in crush at Vijay rally in India
items.content_html:
Victims include nine children at election campaign gathering in Tamil Nadu led by popular actor and politician

Police in India have opened a criminal case against the leaders of a party headed by the actor turned politician Vijay, after a crowd crush at one of his rallies killed 40 people and injured at least 124 others.

Local officials reported that at least nine children had died at the rally, which took place on Saturday night in the Karur district of Tamil Nadu state in southern India. Vijay, one of the most popular and successful actors in Tamil cinema, who entered politics last year, was addressing the crowd for his Tamilaga Vettri Kazhagam (TVK) party before state elections early next year.

Continue reading...

items.title: Chimps regularly consume alcohol, study finds
items.content_html: A new study has observed that chimpanzees regularly eat fermented fruit together, suggesting that alcohol consumption is more deeply rooted in human evolution than previously thought.

items.title: Trump tariffs: Who stands to lose most from new US pharma duties?
items.content_html: The US president's latest tariff move will see the US impose 100% levies on imports of branded or patented pharmaceutical goods from October 1. What could it mean for global trade?

items.title: Legendary journalist Georg Stefan Troller dies aged 103
items.content_html: He escaped the Nazis, then joined the US military fighting Germany in World War II. He later became a legendary author, filmmaker and journalist, known for his unique interviews with international luminaries.

items.title: Trump brags of ‚Äòmassive‚Äô oil deal in Pakistan ‚Äì¬†but drilling has not found any
items.content_html:
Announcement of deal baffles experts and former ministers, who say there is no sign of any untapped reserves

The newfound camaraderie between the US and Pakistan was on full display this week as Donald Trump welcomed Pakistan‚Äôs prime minister, Shehbaz Sharif, and the country‚Äôs powerful army chief, Asim Munir, into the Oval Office, heralding them both as ‚Äúgreat leaders‚Äù.

Having been cold-shouldered by successive US presidents, this was the first time a Pakistani prime minister had been invited to Washington in more than six years. It was also the unprecedented second time this year that Munir ‚Äì who holds no official government role ‚Äì held an intimate meeting with Trump, which many took as a telling signal of where the power to cut deals really lies in Pakistan.

authors.name: Hannah Ellis-Petersen in Delhi and Shah Meer Baloch in Islamabad

items.title: Anti-war: Germany's new peace movement gains momentum
items.content_html: In Germany, resistance against the arms race and militarization is growing. Many alliances are organizing demonstrations. What unites them, what divides them?

items.title: Trump's autism call: What the Tylenol science really says
items.content_html: Donald Trump advised pregnant women not to take Tylenol amid announcing a set of new autism policies. Health experts are concerned. What do the studies cited by the White House actually say?

items.title: Classical music is winning a new generation in Germany
items.content_html: Classical music needs fresh formats to stand out. Creative performers and organizers are charting new territory, drawing inspiration from transcultural musicians across the globe.

items.title: Could UEFA impose football ban on Israel?
items.content_html: Israel has been coming under growing international pressure after UN experts classified its actions in the Gaza Strip as genocide. UEFA could become the first sports federation to suspend Israel.

items.title: Basketball's EuroLeague: Second only to the NBA
items.content_html: Europe's top basketball competition is expanding to a new market as it tips off for a new season. DW fills you in on all you need to know.

items.title: How Russia's mounting economic woes could force Putin's hand
items.content_html: The Russian economy is in trouble. Growth has stalled, energy revenues have plunged, and the budget deficit is growing. If the EU and US step up sanctions, things could get more serious still.

items.title: What is a lavender marriage? TikTok trend explained
items.content_html: Once a cover for closeted Hollywood stars and persecuted LGBTQ+ people, lavender marriages got a Gen Z reboot, offering protection, partnership and a new take on marriage in the digital age.

items.title: Mallorca sees record tourism despite protests
items.content_html: The Mediterranean island looks set to hit a new visitor record in 2025 ‚Äî despite growing anti-tourist sentiment.

items.title: Nations deliver new climate targets ahead of climate summit
items.content_html: With just weeks to go until the international climate conference, nations are stepping up to submit new climate targets for 2035. But will they be enough to prevent a climate catastrophe?

items.title: State of climate change: How healthy is our planet?
items.content_html: Scientists say we've already exceeded seven of nine planetary boundaries contributing to Earth's stability, life support and resilience. This poses a risk, but it's not all bad news.

items.title: Infrastructure: Germany lacks money for new highways
items.content_html: The German government wants to invest billions in transport infrastructure. But it lacks enough money to fund all it needs to do. Will the planned autobahn expansion now have to be scrapped?

items.title: 'Everything has changed here': East Side Gallery turns 35
items.content_html: Once a place for alternative lifestyles, now a monument surrounded by offices and luxury apartments: Few other places in Berlin symbolize change as much as the East Side Gallery.

items.title: Germany's bid to lead in autonomous driving faces roadblocks
items.content_html: Germany has the research expertise, a car production ecosystem and even test tracks for autonomous driving. But Europe's biggest auto nation still lags when it comes to putting self-driving cars on the road.

items.title: US vaccine, painkiller stances concern global health experts
items.content_html: When the US speaks, the world listens when it comes to health policy. Experts say the Trump administration's changes to vaccine and medicine recommendations in the US could undermine health messaging worldwide.

items.title: Why do German footballers struggle to win the Ballon d'Or?
items.content_html: No German footballer has won the prize in nearly 30 years, but a new generation of players hopes to change that.

items.title: How Donald Trump's H-1B visa fee could affect the US economy
items.content_html: Critics say the president's plan to charge $100,000 application fees for the H-1B visa program will greatly stifle the US economy. Universities, nonprofits and tech startups stand to be most affected.

items.title: Unpacking Trump's racist and authoritarian ideology
items.content_html: Authors Jamaica Kincaid, Elizabeth Kolbert and William Hitchcock discussed Trump's attacks on free speech and democracy at Berlin's literature festival.

items.title: Germany fills Constitutional Court positions
items.content_html: The Bundestag was to elect three new judges to Germany's highest court in July. But the vote was canceled because right-wing lawmakers took issue with one of the candidates. In September, the vote was successful.

items.title: Here's how flowers can harvest vital metals
items.content_html: As demand for nickel grows, plants could help suck out vital raw materials from soil. Could this replace conventional mining that's harmful to the environment?

items.title: Ousmane Dembele and Aitana Bonmati win Ballon d'Or
items.content_html: For Ousmane Dembele it was his first Ballon d'Or, while Aitana Bonmati made history.

items.title: Why science doesn't support Trump's Tylenol link to autism
items.content_html: Donald Trump claims to have the "answer to autism." On Monday, the US president claimed that a popular painkiller increases the risk of autism. Researchers say it doesn't work like that.

items.title: Kamel Daoud: Algerian author breaks the silence
items.content_html: The writer's Algerian civil war novel, "Houris," challenges taboos and gives women a voice. The book has made him famous ‚Äî but also led Algeria to seek his arrest.

items.title: Deutsche Bahn's new boss wants to end Germany's railway woes
items.content_html: For the first time, a woman is at the helm of Deutsche Bahn. Evelyn Palla must combat delays, train cancellations and low morale.

items.title: Leo Neugebauer surprises himself with decathlon gold
items.content_html: Leo Neugebauer delivered Germany's only gold medal at the World Athletics Championships in Tokyo. The US college student say it's the perfect finish to a "roller-coaster ride."

items.title: Welcome to 2050: Could Berlin's future look like this?
items.content_html: If Berlin were to become a climate-neutral city within the next 25 years, daily life could be radically different.

items.title: Is the birth control pill destroying women's sex drive?
items.content_html: Decreased libido isn't listed on most birth control pill information leaflets. Yet, research shows it can affect libido ‚Äî just not for everyone.

items.title: Mapping the world's oceans ‚Äî a blessing or a curse?
items.content_html: Oceans cover three-quarters of the Earth, yet only 20% of the seafloor has yet been mapped. The race to understand these depths could further scientific understanding, but also lead to exploitation.

items.title: Could Chinese AI threaten Western submarines?
items.content_html: A new Chinese AI system is said to detect even the most modern submarines. Is it a real threat to maritime security or just a bluff?

items.title: Exiled Russian YouTuber Krasava takes Cyprus club to the top
items.content_html: A YouTuber who fled Russia after speaking out against the 2022 full-scale invasion of Ukraine has not only started a football club ‚Äî he has now won promotion to Cyprus' topflight.

items.title: What you need to know about thrifting
items.content_html: Thrifting is hailed as a cheap and green alternative to fast fashion. But when DW reporter Katharina Schantz set out to find the perfect pre-loved shirt, it made her question what she thought she knew about secondhand.

items.title: Why does sport struggle with equal pay?
items.content_html: International Equal Pay Day, on September 18, highlights gender inequalities across employment sectors. But sport has a series of circumstances that make it a particularly tough nut to crack.

items.title: An Israeli author explores the psyche of a society at war
items.content_html: Author Ayelet Gundar-Goshen writes to challenge fear and prejudice, taking a humanist perspective on the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. Her new novel is a plea for empathy and self-reflection.

items.title: How Trump tariffs are lowering food prices in Brazil, Mexico
items.content_html: US tariff policy is having unexpected consequences for consumers ‚Äî in some places. Coffee is becoming cheaper in Brazil, and in Mexico tomatoes are less expensive. US shoppers, meanwhile, are facing rising grocery bills.

items.title: Bella Ciao: Protest song in focus after Charlie Kirk killing
items.content_html: A look at the evolution of the Italian protest anthem, from its opaque origins to TikTok remixes and feminist marches.

items.title: US Federal Reserve cuts interest rate for first time in 2025
items.content_html: The widely expected cut of a quarter percentage point comes amid economic pressures ranging inflation and tariffs to sluggish job growth. Two more cuts are expected before the end of the year.

items.title: Kenya: Fraud scandal robs millions of health care, pensions
items.content_html: Kenya's pension and health insurance systems were meant to bring people dignity in old age. But fraud, delays and broken promises have left retirees and patients paying with their savings ‚Äî and even their lives.

items.title: Trump at Windsor: Pomp, protest and the ghost of Jeffrey Epstein
items.content_html: Anti-Trump protesters in the UK get creative as King Charles III hosts Donald Trump for his second UK state visit.

items.title: How NIL money changes the game for German basketball
items.content_html: Germany's national basketball teams are enjoying a golden era, but are there concerns domestically that NIL money from US colleges might impact future generations.

items.title: Life in Germany: Free universities, health insurance and paid vacations?
items.content_html: DW's Berlin Fresh and The Washington Post Universe's TikTok teams collaborate to explore the perks of living in Berlin and Germany.

items.title: Eurovision: Countries to boycott if Israel competes
items.content_html: The Eurovision Song Contest is supposed to be apolitical. But Israel is now at the center of calls for boycott and protests, due to the ongoing war in the Gaza Strip.

items.title: Cancellation of Israeli conductor's concert: The problem with cultural boycotts
items.content_html: The cancellation of a Munich Philharmonic Orchestra concert in Belgium over its Israeli conductor Lahav Shani has sparked outrage in Germany. But how does this incident compare to other cases?

items.title: Is the green hydrogen dream over?
items.content_html: Clean, green hydrogen energy has long been hyped as the key to decarbonizing big industries like steel. But as projects are cancelled and investments dry up, what went wrong?

items.title: The 2025 solar storm peak. Should we be worried?
items.content_html: If strong enough, solar storms could wipe out our internet infrastructure. They disrupt aviation signals and, for example, the smooth running of petroleum pipelines in Nigeria.

items.title: Why TV weather forecasters are targeted by online hate
items.content_html: An email death threat marked the beginning of the end of one meteorologist's job. Experts say climate misinformation and conspiracy theories are fueling online hate.

items.title: Is Europe prepared for winter despite lower gas supplies?
items.content_html: Europe's energy crisis may be fading, but Donald Trump's tariff threats on Russian gas buyers loom large. With no gas transiting through Ukraine this winter, can the continent afford to breathe a sigh of relief?

items.title: What to know about the 2025-26 Champions League
items.content_html: The new Champions League season is here and with it new teams, new kick-off times and a new chance for the Bundesliga.

items.title: Film icon Robert Redford dies at 89
items.content_html: Robert Redford, the director, actor, and activist has died at his home in Utah. Redford rose to fame in films like "Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid" and "All the President's Men."

items.title: India and Pakistan stoked for long-awaited javelin clash
items.content_html: India and Pakistan are cricketing nations. But recent Olympic gold medals won by Neeraj Chopra and Arshad Nadeem in the javelin have fans on both sides anticipating the World Athletics Championships like never before.

items.title: How the watermelon became a Palestinian protest symbol
items.content_html: At pro-Palestinian demonstrations, the symbol of the watermelon is everywhere. Artist Sliman Mansour explains how the idea for the symbol goes back to the 1980s and was inspired, ironically, by an Israeli officer.

items.title: Trump turns crypto king ‚Äî but at what cost?
items.content_html: Donald Trump has made billions from the Nasdaq debut of crypto startup World Liberty Financial. With his sons in charge and favorable policies in play, critics see a troubling mix of presidential power and personal gain.

items.title: Africa sees space as 'a means to an end'
items.content_html: When the African Space Agency opened in April, spacefaring countries like Egypt, Nigeria and South Africa came together for the first time. But they have been collaborating with Europe and China for decades.

items.title: What to expect during Donald Trump's visit at Windsor Castle
items.content_html: As King Charles III hosts Donald Trump for his second UK state visit, expect pomp, protocol and perhaps even meme-worthy missteps.

items.title: Experts fired by President Trump revive popular climate website
items.content_html: After cuts by US President Donald Trump forced the closure of the popular climate.gov website, experts have launched an independent successor. They say climate literacy is important in Trump's war against science.

items.title: Germany crowned EuroBasket champions
items.content_html: Reigning world basketball champions Germany have beaten Turkey in the final to win the European championship.

items.title: Crocodile wrestling influencer flouts wildlife rules
items.content_html: American influencer and self-styled "Real Tarzann" is being investigated for illegally wrestling wild crocodiles in northern Australia. Critics say animals are suffering to create viral content.

items.title: The prison economy: Behind bars, everyone's making money
items.content_html: The world spends hundreds of billions yearly to punish offenders, with little return beyond more crime and less hope. DW examines how private contractors, organized crime gangs and inmates exploit prison for profit.

items.title: New study: Cannabis threatens fertility for women
items.content_html: A Canadian study has shown that cannabis can have a negative impact on female fertility and the success of IVF treatments. But German experts say more research is needed on factors like age and consumption habits.

items.title: L'horreur du monde s'inscrit dans un pied de page
items.content_html: Le Nasser de deux ans, dans un h√¥pital Jan Yunis (Gaza).Son p√®re le regarde peu de temps avant sa mort.

items.title: East Germany's Plattenbau: Divisive architecture in the spotlight
items.content_html: A cheap way to manage the housing shortage in former GDR cities, the prefab concrete buildings were long derided for their monotony. Their cultural legacy is now being explored anew.

items.title: Par une d√©fense europ√©enne plus int√©gr√©e
items.content_html: Les avions de combat F-16 dans un d√©fil√© militaire √† Varsovie, en ao√ªt dernier.

items.title: Boris Becker's new book: 'Wimbledon is partly to blame'
items.content_html: The former tennis superstar has written a book about his time in prison in the UK. Boris Becker uses "Inside" to write about his time behind bars, portraying himself as both a fighter and a victim.

items.title: Germany cleans up illegal trash dumped across the Czech border
items.content_html: A now bust German company illegally dumped hundreds of tons of hazardous waste in Czech municipalities. Authorities of both countries have been left to clean up the mess.

items.title: Luka Doncic: Slovenia's polarizing NBA superstar
items.content_html: Germany have defeated Slovenia and Luka Doncic to reach the semifinals of EuroBasket 2025. The Los Angeles Lakers star may be virtually unstoppable, but he does have his weaknesses.

items.title: Spanish legal case leads fight against livestock pollution
items.content_html: A Spanish court ruling on pollution from industrial pig farming could have far-reaching implications for how animals are kept across Europe.

items.title: NASA rover discovers potential signs of ancient life on Mars
items.content_html: The discovery is among the strongest evidence yet that the red planet may have once harbored life. . However, scientists say more study is needed, ideally in labs on Earth.

items.title: IAA: Why VW and other carmakers are changing their EV designs
items.content_html: Electric cars are supposed to be the future. So why are German carmakers now taking a page from past designs? Steven Beardsly reports from the IAA Mobility show in Munich.

items.title: Germany's state-owned KfW bank linked to rights violations
items.content_html: The government's development bank is accused of backing harmful projects in emerging markets. Instead of uplifting communities, a new report says investments fail to protect human rights and silence those who speak out.

items.title: Space law crisis: Outer space security in an insecure world
items.content_html: If we can't get along on Earth, how will we ever get along in space, right? Experts told DW there are reasons to be optimistic.

items.title: EU to slash food and fast fashion waste
items.content_html: EU lawmakers have given a final green light to a law on slashing the mountains of food wasted in Europe each year, and curbing the environmental impact of fast fashion.

items.title: Did AI save Google from being broken apart by regulators?
items.content_html: The growing power of artificial intelligence was a deciding factor in a court's decision not to break up Google and its Chrome search browser. It is another reminder of the expanding influence of AI.

items.title: Could France's economic turmoil spark eurozone debt crisis?
items.content_html: The collapse of the French government over its inability to bring austerity measures through parliament is raising fears that the debt of the EU's second-largest economy is spinning out of control.

items.title: Coca-Cola rebrands products in Germany amid US image crisis
items.content_html: As the global reputation of US brands slips, some US firms are turning to unusual marketing strategies. Coca-Cola, for instance, is now promoting itself as a "German product."

items.title: Egypt, Sudan worry about water as Ethiopia's huge new dam opens
items.content_html: Ethiopia has high hopes for its Grand Ethiopian Renaissance Dam, which is expected to double the nation's electricity capacity. But the mega dam has long been a source of tension with neighbors Sudan and Egypt.

items.title: Germany bounce back with win vs. Northern Ireland
items.content_html: After their football World Cup qualifying campaign got off to a disastrous start, Germany responded with a win over Northern Ireland.
